thread.title: AL Division Series capsule: Astros vs. Royals
thread.title_full: AL Division Series capsule: Astros vs. Royals

title: AL Division Series capsule: Astros vs. Royals
text:
USA TODAY Sports' Bob Nightengale breaks down the American League field and gives his pick for the AL champion. USA TODAY Sports
Lorenzo Cain batted .307 with 16 home runs this season. (Photo: Denny Medley, USA TODAY Sports)
CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE A capsule look at the American League Division Series between the Houston Astros and Kansas City Royals:
(Times Eastern; *-if necessary):
Game 1 : Astros (Collin McHugh, 19-7, 3.89 ERA) at Royals (Yordano Ventura, 13-8, 4.08 ERA), Thursday, 7:30 p.m., Fox Sports 1
Game 2 : Astros (Scott Kazmir, 7-11, 3.10 ERA) at Royals (Johnny Cueto, 4-7, 4.76 ERA), Friday, 3:30 p.m., Fox Sports 1
Game 3 : Royals (Edinson Volquez, 13-9, 3.55 ERA) at Astros (Dallas Keuchel, 20-8, 2.48 ERA), Sunday, 4 p.m., MLB Network
Game 4*: Royals (TBA) at Astros (TBA), Monday, TBD
Game 5*: Astros (TBA) at Royals (TBA), Wednesday, TBD
***
USA TODAY
AL Division Series capsule: Blue Jays vs. Rangers
The case for the Astros: Houston has a lot more home-run power than the Royals, with a deep lineup that hit 230 long balls during the regular season and two against the New York Yankees in the wild-card game. They owe some of that total to their homer-friendly tadium, but the Astros have plenty of guys that can hit balls out of any park. And though ace Dallas Keuchel likely will be limited to one game in the series after pitching six innings Monday, the Astros boast a better starting rotation from top to bottom.
USA TODAY
Carlos Gomez has his N.Y. moment, powers Astros to ALDS
The case for the Royals: The Royals will have home-field advantage for the length of the postseason, playing in front of the same rabid base that nearly elected eight Kansas City players to the All-Star Game this season. And even with closer Greg Holland done for the year after Tommy John elbow surgery, Kansas City’s bullpen remains strong enough to shut down the Astros’ strikeout-prone offense in the late innings. Plus they’ve got a host of solid offensive performers who did not blink when the October spotlight turned on last year.
The X factor: The Astros sent two prospects to the Oakland Athletics before the trade deadline to acquire Game 2 starter Scott Kazmir. At the time, Kazmir owned a 2.38 ERA and strong rate stats that suggested his 2014 rejuvenation was no mirage. But Kazmir, who yields a lot of fly balls, went 2-6 with a 4.14 ERA after joining the Astros and pitched especially poorly at Minute Maid Park. He’ll have the chance to enjoy Kauffman Stadium’s more spacious confines Friday.
USA TODAY
The Walkoff Podcast: Previewing the ALDS between the Astros and Royals, Blue Jays and Rangers
Close and late: The Astros got steady work out of closer Luke Gregerson and stellar seasons from setup men Tony Sipp and Will Harris, but their bullpen as a whole struggled to the tune of a 5.63 ERA from the start of September through the end of the regular season. The Royals, meanwhile, have about the best bullpen in the game even with Holland out. Wade Davis, who finished the regular season with an astonishing 0.94 ERA, now serves as the club’s closer, with fireballer Kelvin Herrera and veteran Ryan Madson as his primary setup men.
In the end: Houston’s offense scores early and often against the Royals’ starters, mitigating the strength of Kansas City’s bullpen. Astros in 4.
